candidates.title: Cargo.toml updates
candidates.body:
Update packages to latest versions.

Get the repository ready for a cargo audit (query -> bpf_query)

candidates.title: perf_buffer: switch to new libbpf v0.6 perf_buffer__new() API
candidates.body:
Start using new perf_buffer__new() API variant that's going to be the
only one in libbpf 1.0.

Signed-off-by: Andrii Nakryiko <andrii@kernel.org>

candidates.title: libbpf-cargo: release version 0.9.3
candidates.body:
Bump the version to enforce libbpf-sys 0.5.0-2 dependency.

Signed-off-by: Andrii Nakryiko <andrii@kernel.org>

candidates.title: libbpf-rs: Release 0.14.0
candidates.body:
Fix the issue with:

```
error[E0063]: missing fields `__bindgen_padding_0` and
`__bindgen_padding_1` in initializer of `bpf_object_open_opts`
  -->
  /home/andriin/.cargo/registry/src/github.com-1ecc6299db9ec823/libbpf-rs-0.13.0/src/object.rs:62:9
     |
     62 |         libbpf_sys::bpf_object_open_opts {
        |         ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ missing
	`__bindgen_padding_0` and `__bindgen_padding_1`
```

This is supposed to be fixed with the libbpf-sys update to 0.5.0-2 ([0]).

  [0] https://github.com/libbpf/libbpf-rs/issues/142#issuecomment-963635219

Signed-off-by: Andrii Nakryiko <andrii@kernel.org>

candidates.title: Add set_print, to send libbpf output to a callback
candidates.body: I want to be able to send output from libbpf-rs to the `log` crate and filter it by level, along with all the other chatter my application produces. Right now the best I can do is send it to stderr. This PR adds `set_print`, which allows a user-defined callback to receive libbpf output.

candidates.title: Bump libbpf-sys to 0.5.0-1 plus a few more dependencies
candidates.body: In preparation for a new below release

candidates.title: Capable using libbpf
candidates.body:
Hi Guys,
I'm new to a few things - Rust and ebpfs. @anakryiko's your blog posts a good starting point resource when approaching ebpfs from a high level language. I had a few issues with my dev env that @danobi helped with- ty for that. I took the suggestion in the blogposts and partially converted [capable(8)](https://github.com/iovisor/bcc/blob/master/tools/capable.py) to contribute as an example here and possibly contribute more to this repo, if I can. I say partially because:

* [filter_by_containers()](https://github.com/iovisor/bcc/blob/0120770f3cdcd0540861e2f92c4f796fe09c3ff6/src/python/bcc/containers.py#L73) is a cool helper function in bcc. I thought of implementing it myself, coz it seems to be doable. But I thought, it would be better if it was implemented in someway through ``bpf_helpers.h``. I also noticed all libbpf converted tools that had this function used in their bcc versions just decided to ignore it and not implement the ``--cgroupmap`` and 
``--mntnsmap`` options
* [These](https://github.com/iovisor/bcc/blob/0120770f3cdcd0540861e2f92c4f796fe09c3ff6/tools/capable.py#L261) 4 lines of code hide a whole lot of code that is provided by BCC to do stacktrace stuff. I noticed that libbpf-tools that dealt with stack traces used @ethercflow's(your blog posts helped as well) code in ``trace_helpers``. I was wondering why it's not part of libbpf and by extension libbpf-rs, since a lot of the converted tools do use that and bcc provides that. Hence the stacktrace options are a no-op right now
* The blogposts talk about considering using ``raw_tp/fentry/fexit`` instead of ``tracepoint/kprobe/kretprobe``.  Bcc had a few helper functions around detecting the presence of these features. I thought I could use ``LINUX_KERNEL_VERSION >= KERNEL_VERSION(x, y, z)`` to get around this. But then I saw how a few libbpf-tools did it by using ``fentry_exists(name, mod)`` which made me think its not that simple. However, that function is also part of ``trace_helpers`` - not libbpf.  After detection of those features, libbpf lets you disable autoload. But, I don't think thats possible in libbf-rs right now. The disable autoload exists in ``libbpf_sys`` and is exposed through ``libbpf_rs`` - but the ``bpf_program`` is a private member of the generated code and hence can't be passed over. So for now I just have the ``kprobe`` implemented. Till this detection and autoload disabling  is possible, the ``fentry`` version probably stays commented.

Apart from the request to absorb ``trace_helpers``, I thought it would be cool to actually distribute the latest ``vmlinux.h`` within libbpf and libbpf-rs/cargo(I have a feeling rustaceans might oppose this) to be used in development because I just noticed that I have the same ``vmlinux.h`` as the ``runqslower`` example. 

Also, if you noticed bcc capable  has a lot of ``#ifdefs`` in structs that are controlled by user args, probably to reduce struct size if those options aren't used. I know thats not possible as-is with libbpf, any suggestions on how to achieve this in a smart manner? 

All comments, thoughts and code reviews are highly appreciated :)

repo.name: libbpf-rs
repo.description: Minimal and opinionated eBPF tooling for the Rust ecosystem
